verses.text: Now I remind you, brothers, of the gospel I preached to you, which you received, in which you stand,
verses.comment: Paul begins by recalling the foundational message of the gospel, emphasizing the necessity of receiving and standing firm in it. This connects with his earlier stress on the centrality of the apostolic teaching.

verses.text: and by which you are being saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you—unless you believed in vain.
verses.comment: Salvation is an ongoing process, not simply a one-time event. Paul underscores perseverance in faith, suggesting that holding to the gospel’s truth is necessary for salvation.

verses.text: For I delivered to you as of first importance what I also received: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes the tradition he received and passed on. The death of Christ 'for our sins' fulfills prophecy (see Isaiah 53), affirming the continuity from Old to New Covenant.

verses.text: and that He was buried, and that He was raised on the third day according to the Scriptures,
verses.comment: Christ’s burial confirms the reality of His death. His resurrection fulfills Old Testament prophecy and stands at the center of Christian faith.

verses.text: and that He appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve.
verses.comment: The appearances of the risen Christ to Cephas (Peter) and then to the apostles validate the reality of His resurrection and the authority of the apostles in witnessing to it.

verses.text: After that, He appeared to more than five hundred brothers at once, most of whom are still alive, though some have fallen asleep.
verses.comment: Paul appeals to living eyewitnesses of the resurrection, strengthening the historical reliability of the gospel.

verses.text: Then He appeared to James, then to all the apostles.
verses.comment: James, likely the Lord’s brother, and the apostles are listed as authoritative witnesses, reinforcing the apostolic foundation of the faith.

verses.text: Last of all, as to one untimely born, He appeared also to me.
verses.comment: Paul refers to his unique encounter with the risen Lord, highlighting the transformative power of God’s grace.

verses.text: For I am the least of the apostles, unworthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
verses.comment: Paul’s humility recalls his past as a persecutor. His apostleship is a result of divine mercy, underscoring the importance of conversion.

verses.text: But by the grace of God I am what I am, and His grace toward me was not in vain. On the contrary, I labored more than all of them—yet not I, but the grace of God that is with me.
verses.comment: Paul attributes his apostolic work to divine grace, not personal merit. The synergy of human cooperation with grace is highlighted.

verses.text: Whether then it was I or they, so we preach and so you believed.
verses.comment: The substance of the gospel is consistent regardless of which apostle preaches. Unity in doctrine underpins authentic Christian faith.

verses.text: Now if Christ is proclaimed as raised from the dead, how can some of you say there is no resurrection of the dead?
verses.comment: Paul addresses error regarding the resurrection, affirming the essential link between Christ’s resurrection and the future resurrection of believers.

verses.text: But if there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised.
verses.comment: Paul demonstrates that to deny the resurrection is to undermine Christ’s own victory over death.

verses.text: And if Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain, and your faith is also in vain.
verses.comment: The resurrection is the cornerstone of Christian faith. Without it, all preaching and belief are empty.

verses.text: Moreover, we are found to be false witnesses of God, because we testified about God that He raised Christ, whom He did not raise, if in fact the dead are not raised.
verses.comment: If the resurrection is denied, the apostles’ testimony is rendered a lie—a serious charge.

verses.text: For if the dead are not raised, not even Christ has been raised.
verses.comment: Paul repeats the logical consequence of denying bodily resurrection.

verses.text: And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile; you are still in your sins.
verses.comment: The resurrection completes the work of salvation. Without it, sin would not be defeated.

verses.text: Then those also who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished.
verses.comment: ‘Fallen asleep’ is a euphemism for death, emphasizing hope in future resurrection.

verses.text: If in Christ we have hope in this life only, we are of all people most to be pitied.
verses.comment: Christian hope is fundamentally rooted in eternal life, not just temporal blessing.

verses.text: But in fact Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.
verses.comment: Christ is the 'firstfruits', a term from the Old Testament harvest, symbolizing the beginning of the resurrection for all believers.

verses.text: For as by a man came death, by a man came also the resurrection of the dead.
verses.comment: The contrast between Adam and Christ (second Adam) anchors the doctrine of original sin and redemption.

verses.text: For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ shall all be made alive.
verses.comment: Verse provides strong support for a corporate understanding of salvation: all in Adam inherit death; all in Christ receive life.

verses.text: But each in his own order: Christ, the firstfruits, then at His coming those who belong to Christ.
verses.comment: Paul sets an order for resurrection: Christ’s, then the resurrection of believers at His Parousia. This points toward the ordered unfolding of salvation.

verses.text: Then comes the end, when He delivers the kingdom to God the Father after destroying every rule and every authority and power.
verses.comment: Christ’s final act is to hand over the fully perfected kingdom to the Father, after conquering all opposition.

verses.text: For He must reign until He has put all His enemies under His feet.
verses.comment: Cites Psalm 110, showing Christ’s ongoing royal authority until all enemies are subdued.

verses.text: The last enemy to be destroyed is death.
verses.comment: Final victory is Christ’s destruction of death itself, referred to in both prophecy and Revelation.

verses.text: For, ‘God has put all things in subjection under His feet.’ But when it says, ‘all things are put in subjection,’ it is clear that He is excepted who put all things in subjection under Him.
verses.comment: Paul carefully distinguishes Christ’s authority in relation to the Father, referencing Psalm 8.

verses.text: When all things are subjected to Him, then the Son Himself will also be subjected to Him who put all things in subjection under Him, that God may be all in all.
verses.comment: This verse shows the perfect unity and order in the Godhead: the mission of the Son culminating in perfect communion.

verses.text: Otherwise, what will they do who are baptized for the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are they baptized for them?
verses.comment: A difficult verse; Paul refers to a practice possibly unique to Corinth. It demonstrates early Christians believed in the necessity of resurrection and the efficacy of action on behalf of others—a sign of sacramental economy.

verses.text: And why are we in danger every hour?
verses.comment: The apostolic readiness to face death only makes sense if resurrection is real.

verses.text: I protest, brothers, by my pride in you—which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord—I die every day!
verses.comment: Paul’s daily 'death' refers to a life of self-sacrifice in union with Christ, echoing Jesus' call to take up one's cross.

verses.text: If with human motives I fought with beasts at Ephesus, what does it profit me? If the dead are not raised, ‘Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.’
verses.comment: Without hope of resurrection, life loses transcendence and moral direction.

verses.text: Do not be deceived: ‘Bad company corrupts good morals.’
verses.comment: A proverb warning that association with the faithless can undermine Christian virtue.

verses.text: Wake up from your drunken stupor, as is right, and do not go on sinning. For some have no knowledge of God. I say this to your shame.
verses.comment: Paul calls for sobriety and holiness, tying proper living to orthodox belief.

verses.text: But someone will say, ‘How are the dead raised? With what kind of body do they come?’
verses.comment: Paul anticipates objections about the nature of resurrection bodies.

verses.text: Foolish one! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
verses.comment: Paul uses the seed analogy to explain transformation through death—a pointer to mystical death and rebirth.

verses.text: And what you sow is not the body that is to be, but a bare seed, perhaps of wheat or some other grain.
verses.comment: Resurrection life is different in kind; our mortal bodies are a seed of what is to come.

verses.text: But God gives it a body as He has chosen, and to each kind of seed its own body.
verses.comment: God’s creative power shapes resurrection as He wills, reflecting His original creative authority.

verses.text: For not all flesh is the same, but there is one kind for humans, another for animals, another for birds, and another for fish.
verses.comment: Different kinds of bodies exist even now; God can provide new, transformed ones.

verses.text: There are heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the glory of the heavenly is of one kind, and the glory of the earthly is of another.
verses.comment: Paul makes a distinction between present, earthly bodies and glorified, resurrected forms.

verses.text: There is one glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for star differs from star in glory.
verses.comment: Paul compares differing glories to show the resurrected will outshine our present mortal existence.

verses.text: So it is with the resurrection of the dead. What is sown is perishable; what is raised is imperishable.
verses.comment: The risen body will be immortal, unlike our present, perishable forms.

verses.text: It is sown in dishonor; it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness; it is raised in power.
verses.comment: The transformation is total—glory replaces dishonor, power replaces weakness.

verses.text: It is sown a natural body; it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body.
verses.comment: ‘Spiritual’ does not mean immaterial, but a body transformed and empowered by God’s Spirit—a vital distinction from mere symbolic interpretations.

verses.text: So it is written, ‘The first man Adam became a living being’; the last Adam became a life-giving Spirit.
verses.comment: Paul quotes Genesis and contrasts Adam, the natural progenitor, with Christ, the source of resurrection and life. This undergirds a high christology, showing Christ as the new Adam.

verses.text: But it is not the spiritual that is first but the natural, and then the spiritual.
verses.comment: There is an order to God’s plan: first the natural life, then the transformed, spiritual life in Christ.

verses.text: The first man was from the earth, made of dust; the second man is from heaven.
verses.comment: Paul directly affirms the heavenly origin of the glorified Christ, increasing the emphasis on Jesus’ divinity.

verses.text: As was the man of dust, so also are those who are of dust; and as is the man of heaven, so also are those who are of heaven.
verses.comment: Believers are transformed by union with the risen Christ, becoming sharers in His heavenly life.

verses.text: Just as we have borne the image of the man of dust, we shall also bear the image of the man of heaven.
verses.comment: This text highlights the glorification of believers—a future inheritance grounded in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: Now this I declare, brothers: Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, nor does the perishable inherit the imperishable.
verses.comment: Earthly, perishable life cannot enter God’s eternal kingdom—spiritual rebirth and transformation are necessary.

verses.text: Behold! I tell you a mystery. We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed,
verses.comment: Paul’s use of ‘mystery’ signals a truth revealed by God: even those still alive at Christ’s return will undergo transformation.

verses.text: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we shall be changed.
verses.comment: Resurrection and transformation will occur suddenly at Christ’s coming, using the trumpet imagery from Scripture.

verses.text: For this perishable body must put on the imperishable, and this mortal body must put on immortality.
verses.comment: Paul employs clothing imagery typical of sacramental language, reflecting the spiritual reality of resurrection.

verses.text: When the perishable puts on the imperishable, and the mortal puts on immortality, then will come to pass the saying that is written: ‘Death is swallowed up in victory.’
verses.comment: Paul quotes Isaiah, affirming the complete defeat of death through the resurrection—a promise already won by Christ.

verses.text: ‘O death, where is your victory? O death, where is your sting?’
verses.comment: Paul taunts death, echoing Hosea’s prophecy. The sting of death is utterly removed in Christ.

verses.text: The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
verses.comment: Sin gives death power, and the law reveals sin; Christ conquers both.

verses.text: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Victory is a gift of grace, mediated through Jesus Christ—the only true source of rising above sin and death.

verses.text: Therefore, my beloved brothers, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that in the Lord your labor is not in vain.
verses.comment: Paul closes by urging unwavering hope and faithful action, for labor in Christ partakes of the everlasting victory won through the resurrection. This verse ties together faith, hope, and love as works that endure eternally.
